Con el Préstamo de S/. 1 200.00 que será devuelto en 6 meses, comprará artículos, como: agujas, hilos, cintas, blondas, colonias, talcos, desodorantes, medicamentos, ungüentos, mentol, alcohol, adorno para el cabello y juguetes doto esto en docenas, de esa manera ella lo surte para que los clientes encuentren lo que desean. Tiene 36 años y 1 hijo, esta contenta por que se siente mas realizada, independiente y con ganas de seguir adelante y deseosa de tener un local propio.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise for her general store.

loans.name: Menyikwa Agri Business Self-Help Group

texts.en:
Martha K. is an average young Kenyan, married with 4 children of her own and 1 orphan child of her late sister.

Martha started her tailoring business two years ago after completing her tailoring course in Kisii town. Before venturing into the tailoring business, Martha used to sell cereals in the Kisii market, a business that she did for five years. She used the profits from her cereals business and savings from various women's groups to start her tailoring business. She initially started with one sewing machine, but she has worked hard to expand her business and she currently has three sewing machines.

With the little profits that Martha gets from her business, she is still able to provide food, clothing and shelter for her children. But most importantly, she says she is glad that she can pay for all her children's school fees. Her greatest joy would be to see her children go to secondary school and higher education if possible.

With the help of her loan, Martha will be able to purchase more clothing materials for her business. Her long-term business vision is to own a buttonholer and an overlock machine.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To purchase clothing materials

payments.comment: Dear Kiva Lender, Unfortunately, the disbursement for this loan was marked late. However, Menyikwa Agri Business Self-Help Group has repaid $349! It is now 22% complete in its repayment. Thank you for your support of this group. Sincerely, Opportunity International-WEDCO

loans.name: Laura

texts.es:
Laura R. F. is a member of the Communal Bank "Las Trabajadoras." She lives in the Juanjui district of the Mariscal Caceres province in the San Martin region, and works selling groceries from her home.

She was driven to start this business by her desire to put her two children through school, and she also really enjoys the on-going contact she has with her friends and customers.

With this loan of S/. 1500.00 (local currency, nuevo soles), to be paid in six months, Laura will purchase groceries such as: cartons of soap, packages of toilet paper, cans of fish, liters of oil, and soft drinks to offer to her customers.

Laura is 36, has two children, and both she and her husband work in the business. She has always set herself apart by being very responsible and working hard at whatever tasks she undertakes. In the future she hopes to work in wholesale.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Chegezy, Kiva volunteer.

La Señora Laura R. F., es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Trabajadoras”. Vive en la provincia Mariscal Cáceres Y distrito de Juanjui, departamento de San Martín se dedica a la venta de abarrotes en un ambiente ubicado en su propia casa.

Lo que la motivo a dedicarse a este negocio es las ganas que tenía de seguir haciendo estudiar a sus dos hijos y además que le gusta estar en contacto permanente con sus amigos y clientes.

Con el préstamo de S/.1500.00 el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará diversos abarrotes como: cajas de jabón, papel higiénico en paquetes, conservas de pescado, aceite por litros, bebidas de gaseosas , para ofertar a sus clientes.

Tiene 36 años, tiene 02 hijos y junto a su esposo comparten la atención en el negocio. Siempre se ha destacado por ser una mujer trabajadora y responsable con las labores asumidas, sueña con ser mayorista.

loans.use: Purchase of additional merchandise

loans.name: Amanccay Group

texts.en:
“Amanccay” is a small rural community bank of FINCA Peru’s Wari Project, which provides its credit with education services in the rural areas of Huancavelica. Huancavelica is considered one of the poorest regions of Peru and has many limitations being a very mountainous area (altituD. ranges from 2,000 – 5,000 meters above sea level), the cold, the difficulty of growing crops and the lack of adequate infrastructure of roads and communication systems.

BCR “Amanccay”, is located at approximately 3,500 meters above sea-level, in the community of Añancusi in the district of Acoria, province of Huancavelica. The name "Amanccay" comes from a local flower. The main activities of the population are the growth of corn, potatoes and wheat (higher altitudes), and at lower altitudes of the Mantaro River tropical fruits. Most of the population also have cows, bulls and sheep, and at the higher altitudes llamas and alpacas. In the small town the population have some shops and proviD. several services, but the main commercial activity is on Tuesday, when there is the local market, where most people do business.

Currently the bank is starting its first loan-cycle with currently 12 female borrowers and a total loan of 4,200 soles (about 1,550 US$). The loans range from 200, 400, and up to 500 soles. As the group is just starting its first cycle, the group was not able to save, except for the initial loan to start. But all agree to save in the future.

One of the members of the community bank is Isabel Ignacia D. L. C. T.. Isabel has a small “cafetin” business where she sells sweets, sandwiches and soft drinks at the local school. Besides her “cafetin” she sells fruits at local markets. With her 200 soles loan, she will buy more things for her business. Sometimes she kills one of the sheep to sell the meat. Like most people she has a small plot of land where the family cultivates a variety of products and has a small stock of cattle. With FINCA Perú she hopes to have her own savings to be able to buy a house in a bigger town, to work more enthusiastically and with more responsibility and to receive trainings. And her dream….. for her son to be a professional!

Another story tells Epifania M. Y., who has her own grocery store. With her 500 soles loan she will buy more groceries to fill up her store again. And like Isabel, she also has a small plot where the family cultivates a variety of products and has a small stock of cattle, but mostly for their own consumption. Her dream for the future is to buy a house in Huancayo, one of the major cities in the central Andes, and for her children to be professionals. With her savings she will able to increase business, buying more merchandise and selling more. Now that she will be working with FINCA Peru, she hopes to save more, to receive trainings and to be respected as a woman.

loans.use: Buy new supplies for business

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 45769

loans.name: Estela

texts.es:
Estela C. D. T. is a member of the Communal Bank "San Martin D. Porres," and lives in the Juanjui district of the Mariscal Caceres province, located in the San Martin region. She works selling beauty products from her home, at Jr. Eduardo Peña Mesa Nº 223.

For the last twelve years she has sold perfume and cosmetics from companies like esika, Avon and Unique, either by taking orders or through catalogs. Most of her clients are her neighbors, friends and relatives.

With this S/. 1000.00 (local currency, nuevo soles) loan, to be repaid in six months, Estela will purchase various products such as perfume, lotions, shampoo, soap, makeup, deodorant, etc., and she plans to buy those brands that go on sale so she can build up her stock and offer a wider variety of products. This will help her to cater to her customers' needs.

Estela is 60 years old, and lives with her husband and their five independent children, who are very supportive of her as she strives to meet her goals. She works every day with much perseverance and hopes to someday have her own store.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Chegezy, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Estela Córdova D. T., es socia del Banco Comunal “San Martín D. Porres” vive en el Departamento D. San Martín, provincia D. Mariscal Caceres, Distrito D. Juanjui, se dedica a la venta D. productos D. belleza, su negocio se ubica en su propia casa en el Jr. Eduardo Peña Mesa Nº 223.

Se dedica hace 12 años a la venta D. artículos D. perfumería y cosméticos D. diferentes marcas como esika, Avon, Unique, que lo venD. a través D. pedidos y por catalogo, siendo sus principales clientes sus vecinos, amigos y familiares.

Con el crédito D. S/. 1000.00 que será devuelto en 6 meses, comprará diversos artículos como perfumes, cremas, champús, jabones, maquillajes, desodorante y otros productos más, D. estas marcas que salen en ofertas para tener en stock y variar sus productos para así satisfacer los gustos D. sus clientes

Tiene 60 años vive con su esposo y sus 05 hijos independientes , la están apoyando para lograr sus metas, día a día trabaja con mucha perseverancia, anhelando mas adelante tener un local propio.

loans.use: Purchase of additional merchandise

loans.name: Genith

texts.es:
Genith P. D. is a member of the Communal Bank, "Dynamic Women" (or Mujeres Dinámicas, in Spanish). She lives in the San Martin region of the Picota Province, which is located in the Picota district. She has her own business selling women's, men's and children's clothing and shoes from her home, located at 543 San Martin St. Most of her customers live in her community or the surrounding areas.

When Genith and her husband separated, she decided to start the business in order to support her four children. She sells clothing from Peru and America and so far business has been great, demonstrated by the fact that she now has many loyal customers.

She is requesting a loan of S/. 2500.00 (local currency, nuevo soles), to be paid in six months. She plans to use the money to order more women's, men's and children's shoes and clothing in various sizes and styles from Lima.

Genith is a very confident woman. She lives with her two children, who are her main motivation to keep moving forward. Someday she would love to own her own bus in order to provide transportation between Picota and Tarapota.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Chegezy, Kiva volunteer.

La Señora Genith P. D. , es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Dinámicas” vive en la Región San Martín y Provincia de Picota y distrito de Picota,su negocio es la venta de ropas y zapatos para damas , caballeros y niños ubicada en su propia casa en el San Martín Nº 543 desde donde vende sus productos a los moradores de su comunidad y aledaños.

Al separarse de su esposo y teniendo 04 hijos a quienes criar decide dedicarse al negocio, de la venta de ropa nacional y americana en la que le va muy bien ya que logró fidelizar buena cantidad de clientes.

Con el crédito recibido de S/. 2500.00 el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará prendas de vestir y zapatos para damas caballeros y niños en diferentes tallas y modelos, lo cual son enviados desde la ciudad de Lima.

Genith ,es una mujer segura de si misma ,vive con sus dos hijos quienes son los principales motores para seguir adelante, sueña con tener un bus para transportar pasajeros de Picota – Tarapoto , y viceversa.

loans.use: Loan will be used to buy additional merchandise

loans.name: Monica

texts.es:
Monica P. P. is a member of the Communal Bank "Dynamic Woman" (Mujeres Dinamicas, in Spanish), and lives in the San Martin region of the Picota Province, which is in the Picota district. Monica runs a business from her home, located at 248 Jiron Sucre St., selling groceries, candy and other everyday food products.

She is requesting a loan of 1200.00 (local currency, nuevo soles), to be paid in six installments, which she will use to purchase various food products, such as dry noodle mixes, tins of fish, bags of rice and sugar, liters of oil, as well as a stock of soft drinks and candy.

Monica is 32 and very confident of her abilities and of what she wants to achieve in life. Her goal is to also have her own public internet booths, which will allow her to increase the size of her business and ensure the well-being of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Chegezy, Kiva volunteer.

La Señora Monica P. P. , es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Dinamicas”, vive en la Región San Martín y Provincia de Picota y distrito de Picota , su negocio está ubicado en su propia casa situada en el Jirón Sucre Nº 248, en el vende abarrotes en general, golosinas y otros productos comestibles de consumo diario.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1200.00 el cual será pagado en 6 cuotas, comprará fideos en paquetes de distintas variedades conservas de pescado en cajas, arroz y azúcar en sacos en sacos, aceite en litros, además de surtir con bebidas gasificadas y golosinas.

Con sus 32 años se siente muy segura de si misma y de lo que quiere lograr en la vida, es así que sueña con tener su cabinas de Internet y en ella implementar un negocio más grande y asegurar el bienestar de su familia.

loans.use: Loan will be used to buy more merchandise for sale in her grocery store

loans.name: Moragwa Self-Help Group

texts.en:
Grace is a Kenyan single mother aged 37 with 4 orphan children of her late brother. Being the sole breadwinner for her family, Grace is left with the challenge of taking care of the children and has to ensure that they are properly fed, clothed, and sheltered. She got divorced from her husband three years ago and lost two of her own children immediately after.

Grace first started by working as a waitress in a hotel for a friend, who also introduced her to a local women's savings group that she later joined. She started saving the little money she got at the hotel and from the women's group. The accumulated savings enabled Grace to start a small charcoal business from her home.

She eventually started growing her business gradually and then started the cereals (maize, rice and green grams, or mung beans) business about four years ago. With the little profits that she gets from the cereals business, Grace is grateful that she can still put food on the table and give her children the basic necessities.

With the help of her loan, Grace intends to increase her stock of cereals and eventually hopes to expand her business to a wholesale unit. Her long-term business vision is to open up a tailoring business as she is also a trained tailor!

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To purchase assorted cereals in bulk

payments.comment: Dear Kiva Lender, Unfortunately, the disbursement for this loan was marked late. However, Moragwa Self-Help Group has repaid $356! It is now 10% complete in its repayment. Thank you for your support of this group. Sincerely, Opportunity International-WEDCO

loans.name: Nyakwengata Self-Help Group

texts.en:
Beatrice B. is a middle-aged Kenyan mother married with 3 children. She also lives with 2 orphan children whom she has to feed, clothe, and educate. Beatrice is the breadwinner for her family, as her husband is currently unemployed.

Beatrice’s primary business is selling fruits, which she started 3 years ago. She first started by selling fruits for a friend for a commission. She sold in the municipality market in the town of Kisii. From this she accumulated the savings to start her business. Beatrice mostly sells her fruits on a retail basis to her regular clients. With the help of her loan, she will be able to buy more fruits to increase her sales and eventually expand to wholesale business.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To expand fruit business

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lender, 

Unfortunately, the disbursement for this loan was marked late. However, Nyakwengata Self-Help Group has repaid $166! It is now 13% complete in its repayment. 

Thank you for your support of this group. 

Sincerely, 
Opportunity International-WEDCO

loans.name: Ushauri Jaribu Self-Help Group

texts.en:
Mary is a middle-aged Kenyan mother who is married with 2 children.  She also lives with 3 orphan children whom she has to feed, clothe, and educate.  Mary is the bread winner for her family as her husband is currently not employed.

Mary’s primary business is selling fish which she started 7 years ago.  She first started by selling fish in Kisii for a friend for a small commission fee, from which she accumulated savings to start her own business.  She mainly concentrates on Omena (fingerlings), but occasionally also goes to the beach to purchase tilapia fish which she says gives her a higher profit margin.

Mary’s day-to-day activities are quite challenging.  Her day starts at 4 am every morning when she goes to purchase her Omena (fingerlings) from the fish wholesalers.  She then has to rush back home to prepare her children, who have to walk as far as 8 km away, for school.

Mary mostly sells her fish on a retail basis to her regular customers, but with her loan, she will be able to buy more tilapia to increase her sales and eventually expand to wholesale business.  Mary’s long-term business vision is to purchase a lorry and to transport fish for further processing and export abroad.


Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To expand her fish business

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lender, 

Unfortunately, the disbursement for this loan was marked late. However, Ushauri Jaribu SHG has repaid $260! It is now 17% complete in its repayment. 

Thank you for your support of this group. 

Sincerely, 
Opportunity International-WEDCO

loans.name: Wedagni Group

texts.en:
Michael O. is a young Kenyan father. He is 30 years old with two children. He also lives with the orphaned child of his late brother, who perished two years ago.

Michael started his business three years ago after accumulating savings from his former work place, a local petrol station in the town of Kisumu. He currently sells men’s shoes but would like to diversify his inventory to include children's and ladies' collections.

As the bread winner for the family, expanding his inventory would allow him to support both his children and his wife, who does not have a job. With the little profit that he gets from the business, Michael struggles to pay the house rent and feed and clothe his children. With the help of his loan, he will be able to add more stock and increase his monthly sales.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To purchase shoes in bulk

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Pov E. is a married mother of six living in a village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. She and her husband, a mason, have been married for 21 years. Five of their children are in school, while their oldest son is a construction worker.

For the past three years, Pov has made a living by selling firewood. She buys it from a local province and resells it in their village. She is requesting a loan of $1,000 U.S. dollars to buy a saw for cutting the firewood and also to purchase more wood to sell.

loans.use: To buy a saw and wood for a firewood business

loans.name: Sarorn

texts.en:
Sarorn S. is a 64-year-old widow and mother of six living on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River. Five of her children are married, and her youngest son is studying in the capital city of Phnom Penh, about 15 kilometers away. One of her daughters, her son-in-law, and grandson live in her home.

For nearly two decades, Sarorn has earned a living by weaving silk into cloth. In fact, in her living room are three looms: One for her, one for her daughter, and the last for her grandsom. They sells their finished products to a middle man who then sells them in Phnom Penh. To supplement her family's income, Sarorn also tailors as well.

Sarorn is requesting a loan in the amount of $1,200 U.S. dollars to purchase more silk for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loans.name: Sam-Ath

texts.en:
Sam-ath H. is a married mother of five living on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from the capital city of Phnom Penh. She and her husband, a cow farmer, have been married for 31 years. One of her daughters is married, another weaves silk at home, one assists in the family business, and the last one works abroad in Thailand. Lastly, her son is still in school.

Sam-anth used to weave silk at home, but last year she started a grocery stand in front of her home. To grow her business, she is requesting a loan of $350 U.S. dollars to buy more grocery supplies to sell.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items tp sell at a stand

loans.name: Channa

texts.en:
Channa S., a married mother of six, lives on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River. For the past 19 years, she has earned a living by weaving silk. Her husband has also been weaving silk for the past four years. They sell their finished products to a middle man in their village, who then sells them in the capital city of Phnom Penh, which is about 15 kilometers away.

Channa is requesting a loan in the amount of $700 U.S. dollars to purchase raw silk to weave and materials to repair her family's home.

loans.use: To purchase silk to weave into cloth and materials to repair her home

loans.name: Chhoun

texts.en: Mr. Chhoun M. is a house builder who makes around $4.50 per day. His wife makes $4 per day selling fuel and groceries. They live in Thnal Dach Village, Siem Reap Province, and have nine children, one of whom is married. M. requests a loan of $800 to purchase a motorcycle to reduce travel and transportation expenses. This will help to improve income for his family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to reduce travel and transportation expenses

loans.name: Bo

texts.en: Mr. Bo S. makes around $4.50 per day fishing and farming. His wife, Mrs. Khan Chea, 36, makes $2.90 per day selling used goods and breeding pigs. S. and Chea live with their five children in Sramor Thom Village, Siem Reap Province. Their children are young students, so they can’t help to make money for their family. S. and Chea request a loan of $1,200 to purchase farmland and buy fishing equipment.

loans.use: To purchase farmland and buy fishing equipment

loans.name: Ou

texts.en: Mrs. Ou C. Y, 30, earns about $3 per day making bricks. Her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver and earns around $1.93 per day. They live in Phum Thmey Village, Siem Reap Province. C. requests a loan of $500 to purchase a motorcycle for family use.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Kimlun

texts.en:
Kimlun S., 34, lives with her parents and sisters on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River. She has two sisters, who are married, one sister who lives at home, and two brothers who are in school.

Since she was a child, Kimlun has woven silk to earn money. She sells her finished products to a middle man in her village who sells them in the capital city of Phnom Penh. To grow her business, Kimlun is requesting a loan of $200 U.S. dollars to purchase more raw silk.

loans.use: To purchase silk to weave into cloth

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en:
Sokorn N. and her husband (pictured here) live in a Cambodian village located 17 kilometers from the capital city of Phnom Penh. They have two young daughters who are in grade school.

They earn a living by selling fish. They buy them directly from the fishermen and then resell them at a market called Prek Phnao Market. Besides selling fihs, they supplement their income by growing rice as well. Sokorn is requesting a loan of $200 U.S. dollars to purchase more fish to sell so that they can grow their business and income.

loans.use: To buy fish to sell

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Em Anth lives with her husband on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River, located about 12 kilometers from the capital city of Phnom Penh. They have six sons—two are construction workers, two are in school, and the youngest two stay at home.

Em and her husband earn a living by selling firewood. Her husband cuts the wood, and Em buys his—as well as wood from other villages—to sell in a nearby province. To expand her business, she has applied for a loan of $1,000 U.S. dollars to purchase more firewood.

loans.use: To buy firewood to sell

loans.name: Mean

texts.en:
Mean T. lives with her mother and family on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River. For the past decade, Mean has earned a living by buying vegetables grown in her village and selling them in a market in the capital city of Phnom Penh, which is about 12 kilometers away.

To grow her business and profit, Mean is requesting a loan of $300 U.S. dollars to buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell at a stand

loans.name: Phearoen

texts.en:
Phearoen T., 43, is a widow living on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River. She has one daughter and three grandchildren (shown in the picture).

For the past decade, Phearoen has earned a living by selling groceries in a shop in front of her house. She buys her supplies from a market in the capital city of Phnom Penh, which is about 12 kilometers from her village.

Phearoen is requesting a loan of $800 U.S. dollars to purchase more grocery stapes to sell. She also wants to buy some equipment for her son-in-law, who is building a boat.

loans.use: To buy groceries for a small store

loans.name: Ho

texts.en: Mrs. Ho S. makes about $3.56 per day farming and growing vegetables. S. is a widow and lives with her four children in Prey Lean Village, Siem Reap Province. One of her daughters makes about $2.66 per day selling vegetables from home. S. is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase a motorcycle for family use and to make it easier to transport things to the market. The remainder of the loan will be used to breed small pigs. This loan will help expand her business and improve family income.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to transport things to market

loans.name: Sroeun

texts.en:
Sroeun K. is a 52-year-old mother of two grown daughters living in Cambodia. Her village is across the Mekong River, located about 12 kilometers from the capital city of Phnom Penh.

For the past two decade, she and her husband (shown in the picture) have earned a living by farming the land. They grow corn, sesame, and other crops. Sroeun is requesting a loan of $1,000 U.S. dollars to buy a water pump and fertilizer to boost their farm production and family income.

loans.use: To buy a water pump and fertilizer for growing crops

loans.name: Kimseang

texts.en:
Kimseang C., 40, is widow with no children. She lives with her parents and sister in a village about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

For the past six years, Kimseang has earned a living by weaving silk into cloth. She sells her finished products to a middle man in her village, who then sells them in Phnom Penh.

Kimseang is requesting a loan of $1,000 U.S. dollars to buy raw silk use in her weaving. She also hopes to buy a motorbike for her family.

loans.use: To purchase silk to weave into cloth and a motorbike for her family

loans.name: Kimry

texts.en:
Kimry V., 44, is a mother of three living in on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River. She has been married to her husband, a mason, for nearly 20 years. Their home is about 15 kilometers away from the capital city of Phnom Penh.

For the past two decades, Kimry has earned a living by weaving raw silk into cloth. She sells her finished products to a middle man in the village who then sells them in Phnom Penh. To expand her business, Kimry is requesting a loan in the amount of $500 to purchase more raw silk to weave.

loans.use: To purchase silk to weave into cloth

loans.name: Ido

texts.en:
Ido K., 23, lives with her new husband, parents, and siblings in an island on the Mekong River in Cambodia. Their home is about 15 kilometers from the capital city of Phnom Penh.

Since she was 13, Ido has made a living by weaving silk into cloth. Her husband has also woven silk for the past six years. Both of them did not finish primary skill. They sell their finished products to a business man in the village, who then sells them in Phnom Penh.

To expand her business and gain more profit, Ido is requesting a loan of $1,000 U.S. dollars to buy more raw silk to weave.

loans.use: To purchase silk to weave into cloth

loans.name: Rany

texts.en:
Rany D., 33, lives on an island on the Mekong River in Cambodia. Her home, which she lives in with her mother, is about 15 kilometers from the capital city of Phnom Penh. Since she was 17, Rany has woven silk into cloth. She sells her products to someone in her village, who then sells them in Phnom Penh.

Rany is requesting a loan of $100 U.S. dollars to purchase more silk material to weave.

loans.use: To purchase silk to weave into cloth

loans.name: Christabel

texts.en:
Christabel is a 33-year-old entrepreneur with five school-aged children. She lives in Kisumu, Kenya, where she opened a second-hand clothes shop in 2004. She specializes in women’s clothing: skirts, dresses, casual apparel and bed sheets. From time to time, she travels to Nairobi, where she buys a good variety of items at wholesale prices. Her shop is on a prime location along a busy street. That, plus her three years of experience and her friendly attitude, have allowed her to establish a good clientele base. Christabel has applied for a loan of $800 to expand her business.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is 32 years old, has three school-aged children and lives with his wife in the town of Kisumu, Kenya. He runs a second-hand clothes store in a busy market located on Kisumu-Nairobi road. George specializes in selling both men's and and women's clothing. He has applied for a loan of $800 to expand his business.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To expand his business.

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson is a 24-year-old entrepreneur who lives in the town of Kisumu, Kenya. He runs a small kiosk which he opened in 2003. He sells basic, fast-moving commodities such as bread, rice, flour, cooking oil, sugar, eggs, milk, salt and soap. He has applied for a loan of $800 to buy additional stock in bulk to sell to his customers.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To buy additional items to sell to his customers.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is a 33-year old mother with three children. She lives with her husband in Kisumu, Kenya, where she opened her retail shop in 1998. She sells cereals such as maize, beans, millet, groundnuts and green grams in small quantities to her customers. She also sells other essentials such as bread, rice, flour, sugar and cooking oil. Her hard work, perseverance, good reputation and experience, plus a well-established clientele base, ensure that her business will continue to grow despite stiff competition. She has applied for a loan of $800 to buy additional stocks of cereals in bulk. She will also save a portion of the loan for use in case unforeseen circumstances.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Purchase cereals in bulk.

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Sao Y. is a 42-year-old farmer living in the Kampong Cham province in Cambodia. She and her husband Meuy Mau (pictured above) have run a farm since 1980, and currently each make less than $1 a day. They have four children, two of whom work in garment factories, where they make approximately $100/month.

Sao Y. has requested a loan of $500 to buy a cow to help them run their family farm. Eventually, she would like to buy more farmland to use for vegetable cultivation and expand their operations.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 35-year-old entrepreneur who lives in Kisumu, Kenya with her husband. She started her fruit and vegetable stand in 1999. Her hard work, determination and outstanding people skills explain her success, and the fact that her profits now pay her household expenses. Margaret plans to use the funds from her latest loan to increase her income by expanding her grocery business and buying cereals in bulk .

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Expand her grocery business and buy cereals in bulk.

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en:
Chhun Y. E. is a 35 year-old farmer who lives in in Kampong Cham provence in Cambodia. She has run a farm since 1990 and earns around $2 a day. Her husband is a construction worker and makes $3 a day. Together, they work very hard to support their two children.

Chuun Y. E. has applied for a loan of $500 in buy tools and materials for the construction businesses she runs with her husband. Eventually, they would like to use these tools to build a pen in which they could start a new business raising pigs.

loans.use: To buy tools for a construction business

loans.name: Pili

texts.en:
Pili is 30 years old and is married with 1 child, aged 7. Pili is a clothes seller; she started in 2004. Every day she works from 9am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

In the past, Pili has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Yon

texts.en:
You S. N. is a 50 year-old farmer who lives in Kampong Cham Provence in Cambodia. Since 1999, she has helped support her family by planting vegetables, and earns about $1 per day. Her husband, Beach Phea (pictured here), is a construction worker and makes $1.60 per day. They have seven children, two of whom are married. Two of their children are garment workers and contribute $100 a month to help support their large family.

You S. N. has applied for a $400 loan to buy a sewing machine so that she can supplement her income by working as a seamstress from home. She will also use a portion of the loan to buy a water pump to help improve her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and a water pump

loans.name: Hadija's Clothes Seller Group

texts.en:
Hadija is 47 years old and is married with 3 children, aged 16, 15 and 12. Hadija is a clothes seller; she started in 2007. Every day she works from 8am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Zuhura and Christina, who have businesses dealing in fish sales and charcoal sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Ndimyake

texts.en:
Ndimyake is married with 2 children, ages 9 and 3 years old. Ndimyake is a chicken keeper; she started in 2005. Every day she works from 6am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $20 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more chicken for her business.

loans.use: To buy more chickens for her business.

loans.name: Ndimyake

texts.en:
Ndimyake is married woman with 2 children, ages 9 and 3 years old. Ndimyake is a chicken keeping,she started in 2005. Everyday, she works from 6am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $20 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more chicken for her business.

loans.use: To buy more chicken for her business.

loans.name: Jumagul

texts.ru:
Jumagul Z. and her family live in the Khuroson region. She is married and has 3 children. She has a high school education. For the past three years she has been sewing traditional women's gowns. It is a profitable business in rural areas, where all women dress in traditional gowns. Currently Jumagul would like to purchase fabric that is in fashion this season. She needs a little more money to be able to do so and would like to take a loan. She plans to repay the loan within a 12 months period. Her business helps providing the local population with an easily accessible source of clothing.

Translated from Russian, Kiva volunteer

Забирова Джумагуль живет в районе Хуросон со своей семьей. Она замужем и имеет 3 детей. Образование среднее. Уже три года занимается пошивом национальных женских платьев . Этот бизнес является прибыльным в сельской местности , где все женщины носят национальную одежду. Сейчас Джумагуль хочет закупить материал , который модный в новом сезоне и отшивать платья для продажи.Ей не хватает немного денег , поэтому она решила получить кредит. Погасить его она планирует в течение 12 месяцев.Кроме того это поможет населению беспроблемно покупать одежду.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials

loans.name: Saodat

texts.ru:
Saodat N. lives in the Khuroson region. She is 35 years old, is married and has 6 children. She sells milk. She has a small farm with a calf, several lambs and a milk cow. She takes the milk to the local market and sells it to those that do not have animals of their own. She also collects milk from the local population and sells it on the market together with the milk from her own cow. However, in order to increase profit, Saodat decided to obtain a loan and purchase a second cow, which will provide her with additional milk. This will allow her to decrease prices, and will make the milk more affordable. She plans to repay the loan within a 12 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Нурматова Саодат проживает в районе Хуросон. Ей 35 лет , она замужем и имеет 6 детей. Занимается продажей молока. Имеет миниферму в которой живут теленок , барашки и одна корова , которая дает ей молоко. Его она вывозит на районный рынок и продает жителям, тем у кого нет собственного хозяйства. Кроме этого она собирает молоко у населения и продает вместе с молоком , которое дает ее корова. Но для того , чтобы увеличить доход , Саодат решила получить кредит и купить еще одну корову , которая будет давать дополнительное молоко. Это даст возможность ей снизить цены на продаваемую продукцию , что поможет окружающим покупать молоко по более доступным ценам.Погасить кредит она планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase milk cow

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Moa

texts.en:
Mrs. Moa T. is 54 years old, married and has six children. Two of her children are enrolled in school and four are married and live outside of the family’s home.

Mrs Moa T. and her husband are employed by a private company and earn about $7 a day. Because gasoline has become so expensive, she and her husband spend a lot of money taking a motor-taxi to commute to work every day. The price used to be $1.50 on motor-taxi but is now twice that.

This couple has applied for a loan to buy a motor-bike to use for their commute. This will reduce their transportation cost and can save her family a lot of money. ( Mrs. Moa's husband is pictured because she was not available when the photo was taken).

loans.use: To buy a motor-bike to commute to work.

loans.name: Hayrinisso

texts.ru:
Hayrinisso F. lives in the Khuroson region. She raises poultry. She has a small poultry farm in her backyard where she raises chickens, turkeys and ducks. When the little chicks are grown, she sells them on the market. She also sells eggs. Her business furnishes the local markets with fresh poultry and eggs. She has been in this business for the past 3 years. The business is profitable, but the income is insufficient to afford rebuilding the chicken house, which she needs to do in order to be able to work in better conditions and take better care of the poultry. Hayrinisso would like to borrow 3000 TJS for this purpose. She plans to repay the loan withing a 12 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Файзуллаева Хайриниссо проживает в районе Хуросон. Занимается птицеводством Имеет небольшую ферму у себя во дворе, где разводит кур , индюков и уток. Подросших цыплят продает на базаре. Кроме того , что она обеспечивает рынок свежей птицей, она еще продает домашние яйца. Опыт в данной сфере около 3 лет. Этот бизнес дает ей неплохой доход, но его не хватает для того , чтобы перестроить курятник. Для того , чтобы улучшить условия работы , для ухода за птицей Хайриниссо хочет получить кредит в размере 3000 сомони . Погасить кредит клиентка сможет в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase materials to rebuild the chicken house

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Doum

texts.en: Mrs. Doum S., 40, is married and has six children. She works with her husband as a broker, buying cows from breeders and selling them to butchers for a profit. This business generates around $7 a day in income. Mrs. Doum S. and her husband have applied for a loan to expand their business by buying more cows to sell. ( Mrs. Doum S.'s husband is pictured here with two oxen he would like to buy).

loans.use: To expand her  husband's business by buying more cows.

loans.name: Kheng

texts.en: Kheng C. is a 35-year-old widow with one child. She lives in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, where she earns around $1.50 a day working in a garment factory. To increase her income, she has applied for a loan from Kiva to rent a plot of land on which to grow beans, and to buy the seeds she needs to start her new business.

loans.use: To rent land on which to grow beans and to buy seeds.

loans.name: Proeung

texts.en:
Mrs. Proeung S. is 21 years old and makes a living sewing and weaving clothes that she sells to people in her area. She also makes clothing to order for customers. Her business earns about $2 to $3 a day. Her husband earns about $4 a day selling sand. In Cambodia, people use sand for many reasons -- to fill ponds, in the foundations of their houses, or in industrial production. Usually, they get sand from the bottom of a river or from special plots of land.

Mrs. Proeung S. has applied for a loan to buy materials and cloth for her business. She will also use a portion of the loan to buy a plot of land where her husband can dig sand to sell for a profit.

loans.use: To buy supplies for a tailoring business and a plot of land.

loans.name: Paor

texts.en:
Paor C. is a 48-year-old entrepreneur who helps support her family by running two businesses with her husband. She makes about $3 a day producing Khmer (or rice) wine, one of the most popular beverages in her province. People serve it at parties because it is very cheap and does not harm their health. Her husband, Chou Vy, age 50, is a taxi driver and normally makes around $12 a day . They have three children, all of whom are students.

To increase her family's income, Paor has applied for a loan from Kiva to replace her husband's old taxi, which is unreliable and use a lot of gas -- a major problem now that gas prices are so high. (Picture: Paor and her husband Chou)

loans.use: To buy a new taxi.

loans.name: Gulchehra

texts.ru:
Gulchehra D. is a widow. Her husband passed away three years ago and she was left alone with 2 children. In order to provide for her family she decided to go into sales. Despite all the hardships Gulchehra remained optimistic. She has been working in sales for the past 3 years, but she does not have enough funds to be able to increase turnover. She would like to obtain a $1000 loan that will help her to do that. The loan will increase the amount of profit she receives from the business and help supply the local population with goods. She plans to repay the loan within a 12 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Давлятова Гулчехра вдова. Муж ее умер 3 года назад, и она осталась одна с двумя детьми. Из-за жизненных трудностей, ей пришлось заняться торговлей. Сейчас она занимается торговлей уже 3 года, но ей не хватает оборотной суммы, для того чтобы увеличитьтоварооборот. Сейчас она хочет получить кредит в размере 1000 долларов , который поможет ей в ее деле.Этим она увеличит доход и обеспечит население товаром. Погасить кредит она сможет в течение 12 месяцев. Не смотря, на все трудности в ее жизни Гулчехра осталась такой же веселой и жизнерадостной.

loans.use: Increase turnover

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Bugolo Lending Group

texts.en:
Tausi N. is the chairperson of the Bugolo Lending Group in Kikondo, Lugazi. She is 42 years old and married with sx children, and also cares for two more kids. One of the children is an orphan and one is her step-child. They are both in school along with three of her kids.

Tausi's business is buying "mukene" (small silvery fish) from Kikondo to sell in the Tororo district. She's quick to say that the transport costs are worth it because each time she has to move she takes around 80 basins of fish, which she can buy for $400.00 and then sell for $500.00. She can't earn this profit margin if she is stationed at Kikondo in her area. She says the loans have really been helpful because she's been able to stop renting. She would now like a loan to expand her business and buy another plot for farming.

loans.use: Tausi would buy more basins of small fish to sell and buy a plot to farm.

loans.name: Wajjala Ibrahim, Bugolo Group

texts.en:
Ibrahim W. is proud of his job. The moment you ask, he does not hesitate to tell you, "I am a boat transporter." He owns an engine boat that completes four routes a day from Jinja to Kikondo landing site on the Nile River waters. He has been running his business for 25 years.

Ibrahim is a member of the Bugolo Lending Group in Lugazi and loans have enabled him to grow his business. He says that before the loans he had no engine and this made transportation much slower and more difficult. Once given the group loan, he would like to buy another engine so that he can hire another person while he concentrates on his own. He is a 42 year old married man with two wives and 11 children, the first-born is 17 and the last is 2 years old. His business is really good and he has been able to finance his loans promptly.

loans.use: Ibrahim would buy an engine for his new boat as part of this group loan.

loans.name: Mashhura

texts.ru:
Mashhura H. lives in the city of Qurgan-Tube. She is single and has a child. She is 34 years old. She has been working in sales for the past 4 years now. She sells cloths. She has a sales point on the market. She purchases goods on the "Korvon" market from wholesalers. Since she is not married she has to work a lot in order to provide for her family. The new season is almost here and she needs to purchase goods for the new season. For this purpose she needs a loan. She plans to repay the loan within a 12 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Хидирова Машхура проживает в городе Курган-тюбе. Не замужем , имеет 1 ребенка. Ей 34 года и четыре года из них она занимается торговлей . Продает одежду. Имеет торговую точку на рынке в своем городе. Привозит товар на рынке «Корвон», где покупает у оптовых продавцов. Так как она не замужем ей приходится много работать , для того , чтобы обеспечить свою семью. С приходом нового сезона ей необходимо закупить сезонный товар. Для этого ей нужен кредит , который поможет ей. Погасить кредит Машхура планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase seasonal goods

loans.name: Seang

texts.en:
Seang S. is 42 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She has four children, two of whom are married and live away from home. One daughter who still lives at home is employed in a local factory and earns around $2.50 per day.

To support her family, Seang runs a small business selling groceries door to door from her motorbike. On average, she earns around $5 a day. Her husband, Den Lon, age 47, is a logger and makes $3 a day.

In provinces such as Kampong Cham, people meet many of their needs through barter. Some trade cows for rice, for example, because they can acquire more rice this way than by buying it directly. Seang has applied for a loan from Kiva to buy fertilizers to trade for rice. She will use the balance of her loan to buy groceries in bulk for resale to her customers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and groceries.

loans.name: Khun

texts.en:
Khun S. P. is a 29 year-old mother of two from Kampong Cham province in Cambodia. She started a small business in 2007 selling groceries in Phnom Penh, and makes approximately $5 per day. Her husband works as a police officer and earns $2 per day. Together they support their family and pay for their older child to attend school.

Khun S. P. would like to borrow $1,100 to buy goods in bulk so that she can increase her profit margin and begin to expand her young business.

loans.use: To buy wholesale groceries in bulk for resale

loans.name: Abdulhay

texts.ru:
Abdulhay Y. lives in the Vakhsh area. He is 56 years old and has a university degree in economics. He lives with his wife and child. He has a small and close family. Abdulhay buys and re-sells calves. He keeps the calves for some time to fatten up and then re-sells them. The profits from this business support his family. Abdulhay would like to expand the business to sell more calves. Expanding his business will also result in more good quality meat being available at the local market. In order to expand he needs financial help and so has requested a loan. Abdulhay plans to repay the loan in 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva volunteer.

loans.use: To buy more calves

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Pov S. is 35 years old and with her husband, she has two small businesses to help her family have a good living. She owns a plot of farmland growing yams. Everyday she has to go to her farmland to take care of her crops. Sometime she waters the farmland and takes out the grass, which is not necessary and harms the yam crop. After the farm work, she still has three school-age children to take care of. She always cooks and looks after the children and sometime she teaches lessons to the children. Her husband works collecting palm juice to refine to sugar cane and sells it to the local market. Normally, he makes $5 of income per day.

Because the yam output makes more income to support the household, she would like a loan from Kiva to hire another plot of land to grow more yams.

loans.use: To hire another plot of farmland to grow more yams

loans.name: Kofi

texts.en:
E. Kofi is a carpenter and also sells plywood. He is married and has 3 children. Business is very good and he wishes to improve his carpentry service and increase his wood sales.

He is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy carpentry tools and materials.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy carpentry tools and materials.

loans.name: Uch

texts.en:
Uch L. is 34 and lives in Kampong Cham province of Cambodia with his wife and three children. He and his wife Tuy Sron sell bananas to support their family. The couple purchase bananas by going door-to-door in their village. They then take those bananas to the market to sell, and make an approximate profit of $3 each day.

Uch L. would like to take out a loan in order to purchase a motorbike. With a motorbike, he would be able to transfer greater quantities of bananas to the market and increase his family’s income. In the future, he hopes to expand his business even further by purchasing a tractor to transport bananas in bulk.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transfer bananas

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
A. Mary sells charcoal and red oil. She is married and has 3 children. She is running out of stock.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.name: Bibirokiya

texts.ru:
Bibirokiya R. lives in the Khuroson area. She is 52 years old, married and has 3 children. She has a community college degree. Bibirokiya buys and re-sells sheep and goats. She buys the animals at the local market, as cheaply as she can. She then keeps and feeds them for about 1 month and then re-sells them at a higher price. She has been doing this for over 3 years. Bibirokiya's husband is a pensioner, but the pension is very small. The animal sales are the only income for her family. Bibirokiya would like to use the loan to buy some lambs. She plans to repay the loan within 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva volunteer.

Раматова Бибирокия жительница района Хуросон. Ей 52 года, замужем ,имеет 3 детей.Образование средние. Бибирокия занимается животноводством. Она разводит мелкий рогатый скот. Клиентка покупает на местном рынке мелкий рогатый скот( барашков и коз) по дешевле.Откармливает их 1 месяц и перепродает местным жителям по более выгодной цене. Занимается этой деятельностью более 3 лет. Муж клиентки пенсионер, получает очень маленькую пенсию. Животноводство является единственным источником дохода ее семьи. На кредит Бибирокия хочет купить молодых ягнят для откормки. Планирует погасить кредит в течние 10 месяцев.

loans.use: To buy lambs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence prepares and sells plain rice with either tomato or beans sauce  to school children. She also garnishes her dish with vegetables like carrot, cabbage, cucumber, etc to make it more appetizing. She is a married woman with two children. The children are in school now.
She wants to use her new loan to buy more bags of rice, beans, gallons of vegetable oil and vegetables to expand her operation. She hopes to start saving to enable her support the children’s education.
Florence is a member of the group called “Gye Nyame” (meaning Only God). Group members agree in principle to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, beans, vegetables, gallons of vegetable oil and frozen food.

loans.name: Lydia Cann

texts.en:
B. Lydia Cann sells sugar, rice, milk and others foodstuffs. She is married and has 6 dependents.  Demand for her goods has increased and she wants to increase sales.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.name: Chamren

texts.en:
Chamren K., age 44, is a mother of ten children and lives in Phnom Penh. She goes daily around Phnom Penh to cut grass and sell to customer's who own cows, buffaloes or horses and need the grass as food. On average, she makes around $2.50 a day of profit. Her husband is a construction worker building a house, earning about $3 of profit per day. She has three children who are married and live separately, two of whom work, one in a garment factory and the other as a blacksmith. Normally both of them earn around $60 each per month. Two children are students and her other children live at home.

To reduce their daily expenses, she would like to request a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike. This motorbike will be used to transfer the grass after harvest. This will allow her to save in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to ferry the grass

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
E. Robert is a drinking bar operator. He is married and has 10 children. He is running out of stock.

He is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more drinks for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more drinks for sale.

loans.name: Sikujua's Raia Wema Group

texts.en:
Sikujua is married with 3 children, ages 8, 3, and 1. Sikujua is a soap seller; she started in 2007. Every day she works from 12am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more soap for her business.

loans.use: To buy more soap for her business.

loans.name: Judith's Tusshiamane Group

texts.en:
Judith is 42 years old and is a widow with 4 children, ages 23, 18, 15 and 12 years old. Judith owns a small food vendor store and she is a charcoal seller, which she started in 2004. Every day she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $110 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have a shop and businesses dealing in vegetable sales and clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and food items for her business.

loans.name: Judith's Tusshiamane Group

texts.en:
Judith is 42 years old and is widow woman with 4 children, ages 23,18,15 and 12 years old.Judith owns a smallfood vendor store and she is a charcoal seller, which she started in 2004. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $110 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in shop own, vegetable sales and clothes sales

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and food items for her business.

loans.name: Kemi

texts.en:
S. Kemi sells artificial hair, clothing materials and watches. She is married and has 1 child. She is running out of stock.

She is asking $525 as additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.name: Sanobar

texts.ru:
Sanobar N. lives in Khuroson. She is 24 years old, married and has 2 children. She has a community college degree. She is a housewife who also keeps some animals. Her husband also helps her with this. For many families in the area keeping animals is the only income generating activity. Sanobar would like to buy a dairy cow for her family so that her children can have milk. Dairy products are very expensive and her family cannot afford them. So they are all eager for her to buy a cow. Sanobar has requested a loan and plans to repay it in 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva volunteer.

Нурматова Санобар Худойбердиевна Жительница района Хуросон. Возраст 24 года, замужем , имеет 2 детей.Образование среднее. Санобар домохозяйка , занимается животноводством. Помогает ей ее муж. Животноводство в сельской местности является единственным источником дохода многих семей. Клиентка хочет купить дойную корову для семьи.Что бы в доме было молоко для ее детей.Так как покупать кисло-молочные продукты очень дорого и ее семья не может себе это позволить и они все ждут , когда же мама купит корову. Санобар решила взять кредит . Планирует погасить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Yoeuk

texts.en:
Yoeuk H. is a 45 year-old farmer in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. She has been farming since 1979 and earns approximately $1 per day. Her husband is a head construction worker in another village and earns $5 a day. Together they help to support their family of eight, including one grandfather, two nephews, and three children.

Two of their children work as garment workers making $80 per month each, and one son is a construction worker earning $2 a day.

Yoeuk H. would like to take out a loan of $600 to buy a motorbike. The motorbike would allow her to commute to work more easily as well as reduce the family’s overall expenses and increase their mobility.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
T. Mary sells porridge and doughnuts. She is married and has 1 child. The prices of food supplies have increased and is effecting her profit.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more food supplies for her food production and sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more food supplies for her food production and sale.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
K. Victoria sells clothing materials and shoes and also operates a drinking bar. She is married and has 3 children. She is running out of stock.

She is asking to borrow $525 as additional capital to buy more drinks for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more drinks for sale.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
M. Aba is a fishmonger. She is married and has 7 dependents. She buys fresh fish from the fishermen and processes and sells it to her customers. She wants to increase sales to meet the demand of her customers.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more fish for processing and sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more fish for processing and sale.

loans.name: Norboy

texts.ru:
Norboy G. lives in the Khuroson area. He is 53 years old, married with 6 children. He has a community college degree. He raises and sells sheep and goats. His family helps him in this business. Norboy buys the animals at the local market. He fattens them up and then either re-sells them at the same market or sells them to the butcher for meat. This business gives him a small profit. Right now Norboy has an opportunity to buy the animals at a cheaper price. He has decided to request a loan to take advantage of this and to buy some young sheep and goats. He plans to repay his loan in 10 months

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva volunteer.

Гулмиратов Норбой житель района Хуросон. Норбою 52 года, женат , имеет 6 детей. Образование среднее. Клиент занимается животноводством. Помогают ему его дружная семья. Норбой покупает на рынке коз и овец для дальнейшей перепродажи.Откормив их ,клиент продает их на рынке или сдает на мясо в ларьки. Это деятельность приносит ему небольшой доход. В данный момент можно купить животных немного дешевле. Поэтому Норбой решил взять кредит,что бы купить на рынке молодых коз и овец. Планирует погасить кредит в течение 10 месяцев.

loans.use: To buy sheep and goats

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
Justina E. sells foodstuffs. She is married and has 3 children. Her small shop is running out of stock.

She is asking for a loan of $525 to buy more food supplies for resale.

loans.use: To buy inventory for a food market

loans.name: Akumu Mary, Bugolo Group

texts.en:
People are really struggling to better their standards of living and this is what Mary A., a member of the Bugolo Lending Group, is going through but it’s paying. She sells "mukene" (a small silvery fish) wholesale, meaning she works hand-in-hand with her husband in fishing. Though at times she stays behind to dry up the fish and deal with customers.

Some of her group members are her customers in a business she has been running for five years. She sells a basin of the fish for $3.00 and on a good day she can sell over 50 basins. Really, fishing is best for men but, to Mary, this is business. She needs a loan to be able to buy another boat and a fishing net, as well as build a house in the plot they bought previously. She is so grateful for the group loans.

loans.use: Mary would buy another boat and a fishing net with her part of this group loan

loans.name: Saom

texts.en:
Saom C., aged 54, is a true entrepreneur and with her husband has two small businesses. She works making Khmer cake to sell in a busy market and earns approximately less than $1 of profit a day. Her husband is a farmer. Everyday he goes to his field and does the farming. On average, he makes about $2 of income per day. They have seven children, six of whom are married and live away from home. Monthly, most of the children combine their money and send around $20 to support their parents.

She would like to loan from Kiva to purchase a cow to reduce costs, as before her husband rented a small tractor to plow the farmland. This will allow them to save in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a cow to plow the farmland

loans.name: Shaydulo

texts.ru:
Shaydulo G. lives in the Khuroson area. He is 52 years old, married with 6 children. He has a community college degree. His business is raising & selling calves. This is the sole income of his family. He buys young calves at the market, feeds them for about 40-45 days to fatten them up and then re-sells them at the same market. He has been doing this for over 10 years and through this business has made a living for his family. At the moment Shaydulo would like to buy his next calf, but he does not have enough money. He has requested a loan which he plans to pay back in 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva volunteer.

Гулаев Шайдуло Ходжаназарович проживает в районе Хуросон. Ему 52 года, женат ,имеет 6 детей. Образование среднее. Клиент занимается животноводством. Эта деятельность является единственным источником дохода его семьи. Шайдуло покупает на рынке молодых бычков , откармливает их 40-45 дней. Затем продает их на том же рынке. Имеет опыт в этой сфере более 10 лет. Этот бизнес позволяет ему содержать его боьшую семью. В данный момент клиент хочет купить очередного бычка. Для чего ему не хватает своих денег. Шайдуло решил взять кредит сроком на 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To buy a calf

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Agness's Mwamko Group

texts.en:
Agness is 35 years old and is married with 2 children, ages 16 and 13 years old. Agness owns a small shop, which she started in 2007. Every day she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items (clothes and bags) for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in used clothes sales, charcoal sales and food vending.

loans.use: To buy more items (clothes and bags) for her shop.

loans.name: Saida's Mwamko Group

texts.en:
Saida is 42 years old and is married with 5 children, ages 4-19 years old. Saida is a charcoal seller; she started in 2007. Every day she works from 10am to 18pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Zulfa, who has business dealing in food vending.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Sharifhon

texts.ru:
Sharifhon U. lives in Khuroson region. He is 51, married and has 4 children. Sharifhon has a technical education. He is a driver by training, and this is his career. Since his salary is low, Sharifhon, just like everyone else living in rural areas, raises cattle in his spare time. His children help him. The client buys young calves on a market, rears them and then resells them. This business provides him with a decent profit. 3 of Sharifhon's children are students, and his youngest son studies in school. Sharifhon supports his large family alone. Currently, the client wants to buy a new calf and feed. He plans to repay the loan within 6 months.

Улугов Шарифхон житель района Хуросон. Ему 51 год. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Образование среднее техническое. По специальности водитель,работает шофером. Так как заработная плата не очень высокая, да и к тому-же в сельской местности нельзя без этого, Шарифхон в свободное от работы время занимается животноводством. Помогают ему его дети. Клиент покупает на рынке бычков , откармливает их и перепродает. Это приносит ему небольшой доход. Трое детей Шарифхона студенты,а младший сын учится в средней школе. Шарифхон сам содержит такую большую семью. В данный момент клиент хочет купить очередного бычка и корм. Планирует погасить кредит в течение 6 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase a calf and feed

loans.name: Kan

texts.en:
Kan Y. is a 22 year-old housewife who lives in Siem Reap, Cambodia. Her husband, Veng Von, is 23 and has worked as a construction worker since 2003. He earns approximately $5 per day. The couple is pictured above with their daughter.

Kan Y. would like to take out a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband. With the motorbike, her husband would be able to commute to work more easily.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work with

loans.name: Amina's Mwamko Group

texts.en:
Amina is a married woman who owns a small food vending store, which she started in 2008. Every day she works from 6am to 21pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

In the past, Amina has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Rehema and Nasma, who have businesses dealing in food vending.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Prisca's Clothes Seller Group

texts.en:
Prisca is 33 years old and is married woman with 2 children, ages 13 and 9 years old. Prisca is a seamstress and clothes seller (khanga); she started in 2003. Every day she works from 9am to 18pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

In the past, Prisca has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes (khanga) and tailoring items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Catherine and Maria, who have businesses dealing in clothes (vitenge) sales and food vending.

loans.use: To buy more clothes (khanga) and tailoring items for her business.

loans.name: Frank

texts.en:
Frank A. sells footwear. He is not yet married. He is focused on establishing himself in business, and he is running out of stock.

He is asking for a loan of $525 to buy more footwear for resale.

loans.use: To buy inventory for a shoe business

loans.name: Collins

texts.en:
Collins is a married man and he has three children. Two of them are in school. He has been selling pharmaceutical drugs like anti-malarial drugs, cough mixtures, pain relievers, antacids, and other drugs for his village. Due to income to expand his operation, he has planned to register with the National Health Insurance Scheme where patients can buy approved drugs in his facility.

He therefore wants to use his new loan to buy more pharmaceutical drugs to enable him increase sales and income to support his wife who sells fish in the village market and also pay for the kids’ school fees.

He is a member of the group called “Awurade Akae Me”(meaning: God has remembered me). Group members agree in principle to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of anti-malarial drugs, cough mixtures, antacids, etc.

loans.name: Heanh

texts.en:
Heanh S. is 28 and has had a small business selling groceries in her community since 1999. She earns approximately $2 per day. Her husband, Phan Phan, is a vegetable and rice farmer who works from their farm at home. He makes around $1 a day. The couple have two children who are too young to attend school.

Heanh S. would like to borrow $200 to purchase additional grocery products to expand her inventory and increase her business. She believes that the additional inventory would allow her to be more profitable and contribute more to her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery products to increase inventory

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph O. M. Joseph runs a small general store. He is married and has 4 children. He is running out of stock.

He is asking for a loan of $525 to restock his store

loans.use: To restock a small store

loans.name: Sun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sun N., is 65 years old and runs a stand at home near a tourist site, selling a variety of souvenir products to plenty of tourists passing through. She can moderately make about $15 per day in revenue. Her income has been divided into two sources. First, she uses some for her family’s daily expenses, and the remaining she saves for expanding her business and to pay back her loan. Her husband works breeding cows and also assists in her business.

She has seven children. All of them are married and stay outside the family’s home. So right now she lives with only her husband and her grand children.

Furthermore, Mrs. Sun N. has applied for a loan to purchase more souvenir products to meet her growing customer demand.

loans.use: To purchase more souvenir products to meet growing customer demand

loans.name: Rahima

texts.ru:
Rahima A. lives in Rudaki region in a village called Zaynabobod. She is a housewife, but she is never idle. She is 45 and has 4 children. Rahima's husband works as a home builder. And she has an agricultural business; she grows vegetables (potatoes, cucumbers, tomatoes, cabbage and greens). Rahima has a plot of land. After harvest, she sells produce at the local market. Here, in Tajikistan agricultural products are not expensive if they are sold by small businessmen. This is why Rahima's business helps keep prices on the market.

Now, is a new season to plant cucumbers, tomatoes and cabbages. This is why the client would like to purchase quality seeds and fertilizer. This will help her produce a good harvest. Rahima’s children help her after school. They all raise vegetables together.

Эралиева Рахима проживает в районе Рудаки . В поселке Зайнабобод. Домохозяйка, но без дела не сидит . Ей 45 лет и у нее 4 детей. Муж работает на стройке , строителем. А она занимается земледелием. Выращивает овощи( картофель , огурцы , помидоры, капусту и зелень). Имеет участок земли. После получения урожая продает продукцию на базаре. У нас в Таджикистане селхоз продукция стоит не дорого , если ее продает дехканин. Поэтому деятельность Рахимы помогает держать цены на рынке.

Сейчас начался посевной сезон для посева огурцов , помидоров и капусты. Для этого клиентка хочет купить качественные семена и удобрения. Они помогут ей получить качественный урожай. Вместе с ней после школы на земле работают и ее дети. Так дружно они выращивают овощи.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice N. owns a small general store. She is married and has 3 children. She is running out of stock.

She is asking for a loan of $525 to restock her store.

loans.use: To restock a small store.

loans.name: Fatuma's Hakuna Matata Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is 30 years old and is married with 3 children, ages14, 10, and 7 years old. Fatuma is a tailor. She started her business in 2008. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more tailoring (clothes) items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Fatuma M., who has a food vending business.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring items (clothes) for her business.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian  A. runs a small store. She is married and has 2 children. She is running out of stock.

She is asking for a loan of $525 to buy more goods for resale.

loans.use: To buy inventory for a general store.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia A. prepares food for sale. She is married and has 2 children. Business is doing very well, and she plans to increase production.

She is asking for $325 to buy food supplies for her business.

loans.use: To buy supplies and food for her catering business.

loans.name: Tursunali

texts.ru:
Tursunali T. lives in Rudaki region. He is 48, married with 4 children. He does not have a high school diploma. But he is a farmer. He has a large plot of land were he grows vegetables. Now, he needs to harvest radishes, greens and potatoes. He sells these goods wholesale. In place of the harvest, he needs to plant tomatoes, cucumbers and cabbage. In order to do this, Tursunali needs to purchase and prepare seeds and fertilizer. This is why he would like to receive a loan, which he will repay within 12 months.

Туракулов Tурсунали живет в районе Рудаки. Ему 48 лет, он женат и имеет 4 детей. Образования не имеет . Hо занимается земледелием. Имеет большой участок земли на котором выращивает овощи. Сейчас он должен собрать урожай редиски, зелени и картофеля . Продает все оптом. На месте собранного урожая необходимо засеить помидоры , огурцы и капусту. Для этого нужно купить и приготовить семена и удобрения. Поэтому он хочет получить кредит, который сможет погасить в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Kwabena

texts.en:
Kwabena A. is a soap maker. He is married and has 2 children. He is running out of raw materials he uses in the manufacture of soap.

He is asking for a loan of $525 to buy these raw materials.

loans.use: To buy raw materials used in the manufacture of soap

loans.name: Sang

texts.en:
Mrs. Sang S. T., 24, is married with two little children and has started a business in 2005 selling household products and vegetables to the people in her area, making on average around $5 each day of net income. Her husband works very hard every day to help generate more income by working as a motor-taxi driver and generally can make about $5 per day of income. Mrs. Sang S. T. would like to start another business which will enable her to have another source of family income.
